entry.title: DRC Colombia ‚Äì Number Range Assignment for Support Documents (Non-Obligated Vendors) in S/4HANA Clou
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 with Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) for Colombia, and we would like to request clarification regarding the number range assignment for Support Documents (Documento Soporte) issued to vendors not obligated to invoice electronically, as required by DIAN.

Context

  • DIAN has issued one Software ID for the company.

  • Using the standard app ‚ÄúGet Tax Authority Invoice Number Ranges (Colombia)‚Äù, the system successfully retrieves and assigns electronic invoice number ranges.

  • However, when executing the app again, only electronic invoice ranges are returned, and no number ranges related to Support Documents are retrieved.

Key Question

For Documento Soporte, which requires a separate DIAN-authorized number range and resolution, we would like to understand the standard SAP approach in S/4HANA Cloud Public:

  1. Is there any other standard app to retrieve Support Document number ranges from DIAN?

  2. Should Support Document ranges always be maintained manually in S/4HANA Cloud?

  3. If manual maintenance is expected:

    • Which standard configuration apps / SSCUIs should be used to register the DIAN resolution and number range?

    • How should this range be correctly assigned to the Support Document eDocument type in DRC?

  4. Is it expected behavior that ‚ÄúGet Tax Authority Invoice Number Ranges (Colombia)‚Äù only retrieves electronic invoice ranges and excludes Support Documents?

Goal

We want to ensure:

  • Full compliance with DIAN regulations

  • Usage of standard functionality only (no custom developments)

  • Correct and auditable numbering for Support Documents in DRC Colombia

Any guidance, official SAP notes, or best-practice confirmation would be highly appreciated.

Thank you very much for your support.

Best regards,

Juan Sebastian Valencia

The replacement is normally needed, as you are not referencing a taxonomy - it is effectively a plain iXBRL file

However, you should check with the regulator on what the exact specifications are.

 

Marc

entry.title: Getting cozy with familiar ABAP terms on your new BTP neighborhood
entry.content:
Welcome to my second post in the series for ABAPers venturing into the wild world of BTP!
If you missed the first one, check it out here: Git, Grit, Giggle and no REST: My SAP Learning Curve (with Bumps!)

When you‚Äôre learning something new, teachers (or native speakers) love to say:
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt use translations when learning a language‚Äù or ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt rely on stickers to learn piano notes‚Äù.

Easy for them to say!

When I started learning a second language, I translated everything ‚Äî and it helped me big time. Now, after years of practice, I don‚Äôt need it anymore, and yes, I agree translation isn‚Äôt ideal. But that‚Äôs now, after years of fluency (and since my second language is English, feel free to judge me).

Then I started learning piano‚Ä¶ and guess what? I cannot do it without stickers. They guide me, make things easier, and slowly my brain gets used to not needing them. Imagine hearing a sound and magically knowing where you are when you just started? Laughable! It comes with time.

So yes, I think of BTP like ABAP. Sue me! I make silly analogies ‚Äî baking cakes for new technology, comparing tools to houses it helps me SO MUCH. And I‚Äôm here to share them with you, in case your brain works like mine. Tip: I always ask AI to give me analogies when I can‚Äôt understand something.

Spoiler

DISCLAIMER: So far, I‚Äôve only used a bit of BTP and created a foreground app. This post won‚Äôt cover everything, just the key concepts that matter to me so far.

Let‚Äôs start with the analogies and new tools!

BTP World in House Terms

Tool

What is it?

Think of it as‚Ä¶

BTP

The new world

Think of BTP as the entire infrastructure of a city. Roads, electricity, water ‚Äî everything that makes life possible. It‚Äôs not just one thing; it‚Äôs the platform where all your services, connectivity, and solutions live. Without BTP, nothing else exists. It‚Äôs the foundation of your new cloud life.

BAS

Your new home

This is where you‚Äôll spend most of your time. BAS (Business Application Studio) is your cozy new home for development. It comes with tools, templates, and wizards that pretend to make life easier (spoiler: they will, but not on day one). At first, you‚Äôll feel like you moved into a smart home with lots of buttons and no manual.

Eclipse

Your old house

The old house you still visit because you haven‚Äôt fully moved yet. It‚Äôs familiar, it works, but it‚Äôs not cloud-connected and definitely not the future. You‚Äôll keep it around for a while, like that old sofa you can‚Äôt throw away yet.

Approuter

Gate and Reception

Imagine a fancy gated community. Approuter is the gatekeeper,  it welcomes guests, checks their identity, and directs them to the right place. No unauthorized visitors allowed. It‚Äôs all about routing and security.

XSUAA

Security system

Think of XSUAA as your smart alarm system. It makes sure strangers don‚Äôt get in and your house stays safe. Authentication and authorization? That‚Äôs its job.

HTML5 App

The living room

This is where the family gathers. Your users will spend time here, interacting with the app in harmony (hopefully). It‚Äôs the visible part of your home ‚Äî the UI that everyone sees.

CAP

The kitchen

If you‚Äôre Latin, you know the kitchen is the heart of the house. It‚Äôs where the magic happens ‚Äî the backend logic, the database connections, the heavy lifting. Guests don‚Äôt see the mess; they just enjoy the delicious food (your app‚Äôs features). CAP is that kitchen.

MTAR file

The moving truck

When you move houses, you need a truck to carry everything. MTAR is that truck. It bundles all parts of your app and delivers them to the new place so users can consume it.

RAP app

The futuristic building

Picture a modern glass building with IoT gadgets everywhere ‚Äî that‚Äôs RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model). It‚Äôs sleek, cloud-ready, and the future of ABAP development.

 

And now the ABAP analogies

Tool

What is it?

In ABAP or analogy

MVC

Model

View

Controller

Models ‚Äì In BTP, this is your data layer. In ABAP, think internal tables and SELECT statements ‚Äî the place where data lives.

View ‚Äì Easy ‚Äî the screen. Dynpro, ALV, or even a SmartForm. What the user sees.

Controller ‚Äì The logic that glues it all together. In ABAP reports, that‚Äôs your event blocks like START-OF-SELECTION and END-OF-SELECTION. In OO ABAP, it‚Äôs your methods orchestrating the flow.

Manifest.json

The route

This file is the brain of your app. It tells where to go, when, and how.
In ABAP terms? Think of the master program in a Function Group ‚Äî the one that knows all the paths and controls the flow.

CSS

Styles

ABAP doesn‚Äôt really have CSS (oh, the UX pain we‚Äôve endured!). The closest thing? Smart Styles in SmartForms but easier.

I18N

Translation

In BTP, I18N handles translations. In ABAP, that‚Äôs like text elements or the language-dependent texts you maintain for reports and screens.

Package.json

List of dependencies

This file lists all the libraries and modules your app needs.
In ABAP, the closest analogy is the where-used list or even the package structure that shows dependencies.

YAML

Destination

YAML files define destinations and connectivity in BTP.
In ABAP, think RFC destinations in SM59 ‚Äî the way you tell the system where to connect.

GitHub and GitLab

Versioning

In ABAP, that‚Äôs like transport requests. And if you use CHARM? Even better ‚Äî Git feels like CHARM on steroids. You commit (save), push (release)‚Ä¶

 

If you‚Äôre an ABAPer stepping into BTP, I hope these analogies make things a little less scary and a lot more fun. They work for me because my brain loves shortcuts and silly comparisons ‚Äî maybe yours does too.

Of course, this is just scratching the surface. It‚Äôs only the beginning of the journey. I‚Äôm still learning. I will get there, someway, somehow. I hope!

Since I am learning I would love your feedback! Did I get it right? Anything to add or change? Drop your thoughts in the comments ‚Äî let‚Äôs make this cloud adventure easier together!

entry.title: AI is Revolutionizing Sales Order Processing
entry.content:
AI Is Transforming Sales Order Processing in SAP 

Executive Summary

For many enterprises, SAP ERP systems are the backbone of operations. Yet, sales order processing often remains a bottleneck, requiring significant manual intervention. For executives, this is not just a process issue‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic challenge impacting efficiency, customer satisfaction, and overall business performance.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) now enables CIOs and executive teams to reimagine order-to-cash workflows, transforming labor-intensive processes into automated, intelligent operations.

Strategic Challenges

  • Manual Complexity: CSRs spend hours validating emails, PDFs, and inconsistent customer data.
  • Operational Risk: Duplicate or incorrect customer records lead to errors and delays.
  • Resource Intensity: Scaling operations requires more staff rather than smarter technology.

Executives ask: How can we maintain growth while reducing operational costs and risks?

AI-Driven Transformation

AI, combined with machine learning, OCR, and NLP, intelligently processes unstructured purchase orders, validates customer data, and automatically creates SAP sales orders.

Key Benefits:

1. Operational Efficiency: Reduce manual effort, freeing resources for strategic tasks.

2. Error Mitigation: Automated validation reduces costly mistakes.

3. Customer Experience: Faster, accurate order processing improves satisfaction.

4. Scalability: AI scales operations without proportional headcount increases.

5. Strategic Insights: Real-time analytics support informed decisions.

Conceptual Workflow

Customer Email ‚Üí AI Email Reader ‚Üí OCR & NLP ‚Üí Data Validation ‚Üí ML-driven Decision ‚Üí SAP Sales Order Creation ‚Üí Customer Confirmation

This end-to-end automation creates a data-driven, self-learning ecosystem that continuously improves accuracy and efficiency.

Real-World Business Impact

Transitioning from manual entry to AI-driven automation typically yields the following metrics:

  • 70% Reduction in Manual Effort: Automated extraction allows staff to focus only on "exception handling" rather than data entry.

  • 67% Faster Processing Time: Average order processing can drop from 12 minutes to under 4 minutes per order.

  • 80% Error Reduction: Eliminating manual re-keying significantly lowers the risk of incorrect material numbers or quantities.

  • Scalability: Systems can handle sudden spikes in order volume (e.g., end-of-quarter) without increasing headcount.

entry.title: Operation scheduling in a day bucket within SAP Digital Manufacturing Resource Orchestration (REO)
entry.content:
'Enable Day Bucket Check for Auto Scheduling' flag in SAP Digital Manufacturing for Resource Orchestration (aka REO) allows production supervisors and planners to automatically dispatch operations that are planned for a specific day, and a specific day only, while operations that are planned for that same day but couldn¬¥t fit in that day schedule are not dispatched at all and remain in the worklist.

To enable it:

  • Open Dispatching and Monitoring app

  • Go to Settings ‚Üí Scheduling tab

  • Turn on Enable day bucket check for Auto Scheduling

To use it:

  • Scheduling mode must be Find Slot

  • Use By Heuristics (Scheduling Options) mode and Active Orders only

How it works

Imagine that you have a bunch of operations planned for the same day, Jan 9th in our example below, waiting to be dispatched:

To a bunch of available Resources:

If 'Enable Day Bucket Check for Auto Scheduling' is 'ON':

All operations that can fit in their initial planned date of 9th of Jan will be dispatched to all the available resources, while the operations that couldn¬¥t fit in that day schedule are not dispatched at all and remain in the worklist to be manually dispatched later.

If 'Enable Day Bucket Check for Auto Scheduling' is 'OFF':

All operations that can fit in their initial planned date of 9th of Jan will be dispatched to all the available resources, and the remaining operations that couldn¬¥t fit in that day schedule are dispatched to the next day onwards, no operations are left undispatched.

The Key Concept: The Day Is a Hard Boundary

When Day Bucket is enabled, the system treats the day as a hard limit.

It will not overflow.
It will not cheat.
It will not push work just because there is backlog.

If the day is full, it is full.

Real Example

If you have the following scenario:

  • Each operation takes 4 hours
  • You have 10 orders planned on the same day
  • The resource has 24 hours available

What happens?

24 hours / 4 hours per operation = 6 operations

So:

  • 6 operations will be dispatched
  • 4 operations will NOT be dispatched
  • Those 4 will stay in the worklist

Why? Because the day bucket is full. The 24-hour window is respected.

What If Day Bucket Is Disabled?

If Day Bucket is disabled:

  • The system is allowed to spill over
  • The remaining operations can be scheduled on the next day

So in the same example:

  • 6 operations go to day 1
  • The remaining 4 are automatically pushed to day 2

How I Like to Explain It Simply

Day Bucket = ON: ‚ÄúToday is today. Tomorrow is tomorrow. Do not mix.‚Äù

Day Bucket = OFF: ‚ÄúDo your best today. Whatever does not fit, we push forward.‚Äù

 

Do you want to see more content like this? Please live a Kudos!

If you have any questions, please check SAP Community Q&A Area, or comment down below.

Thanks,
Manoel Costa

entry.title: store credentials for destination in MTA file
entry.content:
Hello Experts

I am using the Destination service in SAP BTP, and the destination is consumed by an SAP CAP application (Node.js).

Currently, the destination is defined in mta.yaml, and for an on-premise system (via Cloud Connector) it requires BasicAuthentication.

I want to avoid hardcoding credentials (user/password) in mta.yaml.

What is the recommended and secure way to manage credentials for destinations used by CAP applications?

Any guidance or best practices for production scenarios would be appreciated.

- name: <name>-destination
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  requires:
    - name: srv-api
  parameters:
    service: destination
    service-plan: lite
    config:
      HTML5Runtime_enabled: true
      init_data:
        instance:
          destinations:
            - Name: <name>-srv
              URL: ~{srv-api/srv-url}
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              Type: HTTP
              ProxyType: Internet
              HTML5.ForwardAuthToken: true
              HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
              HTML5.Timeout: 600000

            - Name: ui5
              Authentication: NoAuthentication
              ProxyType: Internet
              Type: HTTP
              URL: https://ui5.sap.com

            - Name: S4_TECH

entry.title: Automatically Insert Dynamic Report Headers in ABAP Report Programs
entry.content:
1. Background

When you create a new report program using SE38, SAP automatically generates a default header template.
However, this template usually contains only minimal information, and each developer often maintains their own static format.
As a result, report headers differ from one developer to another ‚Äî making documentation inconsistent across the organization.

To fix this, we can configure a company-wide dynamic header template that appears automatically for all new report programs.

2. Objective

We‚Äôll make sure that:

  • Every new report program created through SE38 gets the same standard header.

  • The header dynamically fills fields like:

    • Author Name ($UNAME)

    • Creation Date ($DAT)

    • Program Name ($PROG)

  • The change is automatic, no manual copy-paste needed.

3. Approach Overview

Step 1: Update the entries in table TSE05 for APP_OBJ = 'ADDM' and KEYWORD = 'REPORT'
This controls the default report header structure.

Step 2: Add a small implicit enhancement to dynamically populate $UNAME and $DAT.

 

4. Updating the Template in TSE05

If you check TSE05 for: 

APP_OBJ = 'ADDM'
KEYWORD = 'REPORT'

you‚Äôll see the current (generic) header lines.

Table : TSE05 ( Before Change ) 

Now when I create a report program , program header template will be like as below , based on TSE05 entries for APP_OBJ = ‚ÄòADDM‚Äô and KEYWORD = ‚ÄòREPORT‚Äô

But, We need more meaningful Header template and it should be same across organization.

So go to table SE05 

Updated the data for APP_OBJ = ‚ÄòADDM‚Äô and KEYWORD = ‚ÄòREPORT‚Äô as below 

Now when I create a Report program after the change 

Note: If you see  the template, Author : $UNAME and Create Date : $Dat . But we need actual User Name and Creation Date.

So to read these dynamic value entries , we can do a small implicit enhancement where the program fills  value .

Create an Implicit Enhancement 

Code inside the Implicit enhancement.

Once you add the code in the  implicit enhancement in FORM insert_program USING name LIKE trdir-name    subc LIKE trdir-subc.

Now try to create a report program - SE38 

Final Output

You can see User name and Date has been populated. 

Two ways to update TSE05 

Step1: Delete the record from TSE05 where  APP_OBJ = ‚ÄòADDM‚Äô and KEYWORD = ‚ÄòREPORT‚Äô

DELETE

Enter New Data as below 

Conclusion

By leveraging TSE05 configuration and a small implicit enhancement, you can enforce a uniform, dynamic, and meaningful header template for every report program created through SE38 ‚Äî ensuring consistent documentation and professionalism across your development team.

entry.title: Fixing Warranty Inheritance Issues in SAP PM: A Custom ABAP Report
entry.content:
In SAP Plant Maintenance (PM), warranty periods for technical objects are designed to be inherited automatically from superior functional locations to their subordinate locations. This is part of the standard functionality. However, in practice, this inheritance sometimes fails... leading to inconsistencies and manual corrections that consume time and create frustration for PM administrators.

The Problem

Although SAP provides automatic inheritance for warranty start and end dates, there are cases where this process does not work as expected. Common reasons include:

  • Data inconsistencies in the hierarchy.
  • Missing or incorrect object numbers.
  • Technical issues during creation or update of functional locations.

When inheritance fails, subordinate locations remain without warranty data, which can impact maintenance planning and compliance.

The Solution

Instead of relying solely on the standard process, we developed a lightweight ABAP report that ensures warranty data consistency across the hierarchy. The report reads warranty start and end dates from the parent functional location and applies them to all subordinate locations, writing the data directly into the BGMKOBJ table.

Key Features

  • Input: Superior functional location.
  • Logic: Reads warranty data from the parent and applies it to all child locations.
  • Execution: Uses MODIFY on BGMKOBJ, which automatically decides whether to update existing records or insert new ones.
  • Modes: Test mode for simulation and productive mode for actual updates.

Core Logic

LOOP AT lt_child ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<child>).
  IF p_test = abap_true.
    lv_status = |SIMULATION: Location { <child>-tplnr } would be updated or newly created.|.
  ELSE.
    CLEAR wa_bgmkobj_child.
    wa_bgmkobj_child = wa_bgmkobj_parent.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-j_objnr = <child>-objnr.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erdat   = sy-datum.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erzei   = sy-uzeit.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-gaerb   = 'X'.

    " MODIFY automatically decides whether to INSERT or UPDATE
    MODIFY bgmkobj FROM _bgmkobj_child.

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      lv_status = |Location { <child>-tplnr } successfully processed.|.
    ELSE.
      lv_status = |Error processing location { <child>-tplnr }.|.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  WRITE: / lv_status.
ENDLOOP.

entry.title: Creating a REST API (web service) in SAP for Web App Consumption.
entry.content:
Step by step process for creating a rest API (Web Service) in sap, which will be consume by
web based application:

1. Create Table- ZDT_WEB_COMPLAIN

2. Create SNRO Number range object: ZSNRO_WEB

Transaction code: SNRO

Give SNRO name and click on create 

enter short text, long text, number length domain, % warning and save.

click on Ranges--> click on change intervals--> click on new entries.

insert the number range and save.

3. Create request handler class : ZCL_WEBCOMPLAINT_REQHANDLR

Go to Transaction Code - SE24 and create request handler class.

enter the superclass as cl_rest_http_handler and click on save.

Go to method section to see super class methods.

select the get_root_handler and click on redefine. Add the below code in between method and endmethod.



DATA(lo_router) = NEW cl_rest_router( ).  
  
    lo_router->attach( EXPORTING  
                       iv_template =  '/webcomplaint' " Unified Name for Reso  
                       iv_handler_class =  'ZCL_WEBCOMPLAINT_REQHANDLR'   " Object Type Name  
                      "  it_parameter  = " Resource contructor parameters

save and activate the class .

4. Create resource provider class: ZCL_WEBCOMPLAINT_REQPROVIDER.

Go to Transaction Code - SE24 and create request provider class.

 

enter the superclass as  cl_rest_resource  and click on save.

Go to method section to see super class methods.

select the method 'GET' and click on redefine . Add the below code.

DATA : lv_string1   TYPE vbeln,         "string, 
           lv_string2   TYPE string, 
           gs_complaint TYPE zdt_web_complain. 
 
    lv_string1 = mo_request->get_uri_query_parameter( iv_name = 'DOC_ID' ). 
 
    CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_ALPHA_INPUT' 
      EXPORTING 
        input  = lv_string1 
      IMPORTING 
        output = lv_string1. 
 
 
    SELECT SINGLE * FROM zdt_web_complain INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF gs_complaint 
    WHERE doc_id = lv_string1. 
 
 
    /ui2/cl_json=>serialize( 
      EXPORTING 
        data        =  gs_complaint    " Data to serialize 
*       COMPRESS    = ABAP_FALSE    " Skip empty elements 
*       NAME        =     " Object name 
*       PRETTY_NAME =     " Pretty Print property names 
*       TYPE_DESCR  =     " Data descriptor 
      RECEIVING 
        r_json      =   lv_string2  " JSON string 
    ). 
 
    mo_response->create_entity( )->set_string_data( iv_data = lv_string2 ). 
 
 
    mo_response->set_header_field( 
 
      EXPORTING 
        iv_name  =  'Content-Type'   " Header Name 
        iv_value =  'application/json'   " Header Value 
    ). 



save and activate .  

similarly redefine the post method and add the below code. 

  METHOD if_rest_resource~post.
*CALL METHOD SUPER->IF_REST_RESOURCE~POST
*  EXPORTING
*    IO_ENTITY =
*    .

    DATA : lv_string1   TYPE vbeln,         "string,
           lv_string2   TYPE string,
           lv_response  TYPE string,
           gs_complaint TYPE zdt_web_complain.

    DATA(lo_entity)    = mo_request->get_entity( ).
    DATA(lo_response)  = mo_response->create_entity( ).

    "read string data i.e json
    DATA(lv_data) = lo_entity->get_string_data( ).

    /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
      EXPORTING
        json                  =  lv_data   " JSON string
*     PRETTY_NAME           =     " Pretty Print property names
      CHANGING
        data                  =  gs_complaint   " Data to serialize
    ).
*   CATCH CX_SY_MOVE_CAST_ERROR.    "

    CALL FUNCTION 'NUMBER_GET_NEXT'
      EXPORTING
        nr_range_nr             = '01'
        object                  = 'ZSNRO_WEB'
        quantity                = '1'
*       SUBOBJECT               = ' '
*       TOYEAR                  = '0000'
*       IGNORE_BUFFER           = ' '
      IMPORTING
        number                  = gs_complaint-doc_id
*       QUANTITY                =
*       RETURNCODE              =
      EXCEPTIONS
        interval_not_found      = 1
        number_range_not_intern = 2
        object_not_found        = 3
        quantity_is_0           = 4
        quantity_is_not_1       = 5
        interval_overflow       = 6
        buffer_overflow         = 7
        OTHERS                  = 8.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

    gs_complaint-createdby    = sy-uname.
    gs_complaint-createdon    = sy-datum.
    gs_complaint-time         = sy-uzeit.

    INSERT INTO zdt_web_complain VALUES gs_complaint.


    /ui2/cl_json=>serialize(
      EXPORTING
        data        =   gs_complaint    " Data to serialize
*        COMPRESS    = ABAP_FALSE    " Skip empty elements
*        NAME        =     " Object name
*        PRETTY_NAME =     " Pretty Print property names
*        TYPE_DESCR  =     " Data descriptor

      RECEIVING
          r_json   = lv_response
          ).

    " JSON string
    lo_response->set_string_data( iv_data = lv_response ).

ENDMETHOD.

 

save and activate.  

similarly redefine the post method and add the below code. 

METHOD if_rest_resource~post.
*CALL METHOD SUPER->IF_REST_RESOURCE~POST
*  EXPORTING
*    IO_ENTITY =
*    .

    DATA : lv_string1   TYPE vbeln,         "string,
           lv_string2   TYPE string,
           lv_response  TYPE string,
           gs_complaint TYPE zdt_web_complain.

    DATA(lo_entity)    = mo_request->get_entity( ).
    DATA(lo_response)  = mo_response->create_entity( ).

    "read string data i.e json
    DATA(lv_data) = lo_entity->get_string_data( ).

    /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
      EXPORTING
        json                  =  lv_data   " JSON string
*     PRETTY_NAME           =     " Pretty Print property names
      CHANGING
        data                  =  gs_complaint   " Data to serialize
    ).
*   CATCH CX_SY_MOVE_CAST_ERROR.    "

    CALL FUNCTION 'NUMBER_GET_NEXT'
      EXPORTING
        nr_range_nr             = '01'
        object                  = 'ZSNRO_WEB'
        quantity                = '1'
*       SUBOBJECT               = ' '
*       TOYEAR                  = '0000'
*       IGNORE_BUFFER           = ' '
      IMPORTING
        number                  = gs_complaint-doc_id
*       QUANTITY                =
*       RETURNCODE              =
      EXCEPTIONS
        interval_not_found      = 1
        number_range_not_intern = 2
        object_not_found        = 3
        quantity_is_0           = 4
        quantity_is_not_1       = 5
        interval_overflow       = 6
        buffer_overflow         = 7
        OTHERS                  = 8.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

    gs_complaint-createdby    = sy-uname.
    gs_complaint-createdon    = sy-datum.
    gs_complaint-time         = sy-uzeit.

    INSERT INTO zdt_web_complain VALUES gs_complaint.


    /ui2/cl_json=>serialize(
      EXPORTING
        data        =   gs_complaint    " Data to serialize
*        COMPRESS    = ABAP_FALSE    " Skip empty elements
*        NAME        =     " Object name
*        PRETTY_NAME =     " Pretty Print property names
*        TYPE_DESCR  =     " Data descriptor

      RECEIVING
          r_json   = lv_response
          ).

    " JSON string
    lo_response->set_string_data( iv_data = lv_response ).

ENDMETHOD.

save and activate.

5. Create SICF service:

Execute Transaction code SICF.

click on execute. 

 

give the service element name and press enter. 

enter description and request handler class name [ zcl_webcomplaint_reqhandlr  ]and save. 

 

on SICF main screen activate the service.

now before testing add some record in table, then test the service.

entry.title: Quick Start with SAP HANA PAL: Basic Example Implementation
entry.content:
What is PAL in SAP?

In SAP, PAL stands for Predictive Analysis Library.
It‚Äôs a collection of built-in, pre-delivered machine learning and statistical algorithms that run directly inside SAP HANA (in-memory database). Instead of exporting data to an external ML tool (like Python, R, etc.), PAL allows you to do predictive analytics inside HANA itself, close to the data.

Key Capabilities 

  • In-Database Predictive Processing: PAL enables running ML/statistical algorithms within the HANA database itself, eliminating the need to export data to external tools. This delivers high performance and reduces data latency.

  • Rich Algorithm Portfolio: PAL provides a wide spectrum of built-in algorithms: classification (decision trees, logistic regression, Na√Øve Bayes), regression (linear, polynomial), clustering (k-means, DBSCAN), time-series forecasting (ARIMA, exponential smoothing), association rules, anomaly detection, and more.

  • SQL/Script-Based Invocation: All PAL algorithms are exposed as SQL Script procedures. Developers can embed calls directly in SQL or stored procedures, enabling seamless integration with existing database logic without switching environments.

     

    SAP HANA‚Äôs SQL Script is an extension of SQL. It includes enhanced control-flow capabilities and lets developers define complex application logic inside database procedures. However, it is difficult to describe predictive analysis logic with procedures.

    Why PAL was introduced
    For example, an application may need to perform a cluster analysis in a huge customer table with 1T records. It is impossible to implement the analysis in a procedure using the simple classic K-means algorithms, or with more complicated algorithms in the data-mining area. Transferring large tables to the application server to perform the K-means calculation is also costly.

    Prerequisites

  • ADT (ABAP Development Toolkit) 
  • ABAP GUI Logon with system access

    Segmentation Analysis

  • Open ABAP Perspective:
    Window ‚Üí Perspective ‚Üí Open Perspective ‚Üí ABAP

  • Create an ABAP Project:
    Use the left panel ‚Üí Create ABAP Project ‚Üí connect to your SAP system

  • Define AMDP Procedures:
    Create AMDP procedures to define input/output structures for the PAL algorithm

  • Create an ABAP Report:

    1. Fetch the required data
    2. Set algorithm parameters
    3. Call the AMDP procedure to run the PAL algorithm
    4. Display or store the results

    Predefined PAL Algorithms Available in SAP HANA
    The Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) defines functions that can be called from within SQL Script procedures to perform analytic algorithms. This release of PAL includes classic and universal predictive analysis algorithms in ten data-mining categories:

    • Clustering

    • Classification

    • Regression

    • Association

    • Time Series

    • Preprocessing

    • Statistics

    • Social Network Analysis

    • Recommender System

    • Miscellaneous

        Checking PAL Installation 
             To confirm that the PAL procedures were installed successfully, you can check the following three public views:

  • sys.afl.areas

  • sys.afl_packages

  • sys.afl_functions

   These views are granted to the PUBLIC role and can be accessed by anyone.
   To check the views, run the following SQL statements:

 
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_AREAS" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_PACKAGES" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';
SELECT * FROM "SYS"."AFL_FUNCTIONS" WHERE AREA_NAME = 'AFLPAL';


Example for Classification Algorithm

       AMDP class: It acts as a bridge between ABAP and SAP HANA PAL. It allows us to define the input and output structures and call the PAL algorithms directly from ABAP, enabling in-database predictive analytics without moving data outside HANA.

CLASS cl_demo DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES : if_amdp_marker_hdb.

    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_input,
              From_node TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              To_node   TYPE c LENGTH 30,
            END OF ty_input,

            tt_input TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_input WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_param,
              name       TYPE c LENGTH 60,
              intargs    TYPE i,
              doubleargs TYPE f,
              stringargs TYPE c LENGTH 100,
            END OF ty_param,

            tt_param TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_param WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_result,
              node TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_result,

            tt_result TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_result WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_user_count,
              role_name  TYPE string,
              user_count TYPE i,
            END OF ty_user_count,

            tt_user_count TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_user_count WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_scaling_input,
              data_id    TYPE i,
              count TYPE i,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_scaling_input,

            tt_scaling_input TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_scaling_input WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_scaling_param,
              name       TYPE c LENGTH 30,
              intargs    TYPE i,
              doubleargs TYPE f,
              stringargs TYPE c LENGTH 30,
            END OF ty_scaling_param,

            tt_scaling_param TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_scaling_param WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_res,
              data_id    TYPE i,
              count TYPE i,
              rank TYPE f,
            END OF ty_res,

            tt_res TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_res WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_model,
              id            TYPE i,
              model_content TYPE c LENGTH 5000,
            END OF ty_model,

            tt_model TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_model WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_statistics,
              stat_name  TYPE c LENGTH 256,
              stat_value TYPE c LENGTH 1000,
            END OF ty_statistics,

            tt_statistics TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_statistics WITH EMPTY KEY,

            BEGIN OF ty_placeholder,
              param_name   TYPE c LENGTH 256,
              int_value    TYPE i,
              double_value TYPE f,
              string_value TYPE c LENGTH 1000,
            END OF ty_placeholder,

            tt_placeholder TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_placeholder WITH EMPTY KEY.



    METHODS : run_pagerank
      IMPORTING
        VALUE(it_data)   TYPE tt_input
        VALUE(it_param)  TYPE tt_param OPTIONAL
      EXPORTING
        VALUE(it_result) TYPE tt_result,

      run_scaling
        IMPORTING
                  VALUE(it_input)       TYPE tt_scaling_input
                  VALUE(it_param)       TYPE tt_scaling_param OPTIONAL
        EXPORTING
                  VALUE(it_res)         TYPE tt_res
                  VALUE(it_model)       TYPE tt_model
                  VALUE(it_statistics)  TYPE tt_statistics
                  VALUE(it_placeholder) TYPE tt_placeholder
        RAISING   cx_amdp_error.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS cl_demo IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD run_pagerank BY DATABASE
   PROCEDURE FOR HDB
   LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_PAGERANK(:it_data, :it_param, :it_result);

  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD run_scaling BY DATABASE
     PROCEDURE FOR HDB
     LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    CALL _SYS_AFL.PAL_SCALE(:it_input, :it_param, :it_res, :it_model, :it_statistics, :it_placeholder );

  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

To execute PAL algorithms in SAP HANA, we create an ABAP report program. This program calls the methods defined in the AMDP class, fetches the required data, sets the necessary algorithm parameters, runs the predictive procedures, and captures the results for analysis or further processing. 

REPORT zpal_demo.

DATA: lt_input               TYPE cl_demo=>tt_input,
      ls_input               LIKE LINE OF lt_input,
      lr_table               TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
      lt_param               TYPE cl_demo=>tt_param,
      ls_param               LIKE LINE OF lt_param,
      lt_result              TYPE cl_demo=>tt_result,           
      lt_scale_input         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_scaling_input,
      lt_scale_param         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_scaling_param,
      lt_scale_result        TYPE cl_demo=>tt_res,
      lt_scale_stcs          TYPE cl_demo=>tt_statistics,
      lt_scale_model         TYPE cl_demo=>tt_model,
      lt_scale_placeholder   TYPE cl_demo=>tt_placeholder,
      lr_pagerank            TYPE REF TO cl_demo,
      lr_scaling             TYPE REF TO cl_demo.

   START-OF-SELECTION.

  SELECT FROM (Data source)
        FIELDS * INTO TABLE (lt_final).

  "Run pagerank clustering
  CREATE OBJECT lr_pagerank.
  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lr_pagerank->run_pagerank
        EXPORTING
          it_data   = CONV #( lt_final )
          it_param  = lt_param
        IMPORTING
          it_result = lt_result.
    CATCH cx_amdp_version_mismatch INTO DATA(ls_error).
      CALL METHOD ls_error->get_text
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_txt).

  ENDTRY.

    "Parameters
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'SCALING_METHOD' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'Z-SCORE_METHOD' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'NEW_MAX'        intargs = 0 doubleargs = '1.0' stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'NEW_MIN'        intargs = 0 doubleargs = '0.0' stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.
  APPEND VALUE #( name = 'DIVISION_BY_ZERO_HANDLER' intargs = 0 doubleargs = 0 stringargs = '' ) TO lt_scale_param.

  CREATE OBJECT lr_scaling.
  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lr_scaling->run_scaling
        EXPORTING
          it_input       = lt_scaling_input
          it_param       = lt_scale_param
        IMPORTING
          it_res         = lt_scale_result
          it_model       = lt_scale_model
          it_statistics  = lt_scale_stcs
          it_placeholder = lt_scale_placeholder.

    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(ls_scale_error).
      CALL METHOD ls_scale_error->get_text
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_scale_txt).
      CALL METHOD ls_scale_error->get_longtext
        RECEIVING
          result = DATA(ls_long_txt).

  ENDTRY.

 Note:  While creating the parameter table, make sure to refer carefully to the official PAL documentation for the specific algorithm you are using. The structure and fields of the parameter table may differ based on the algorithm requirements, so modify it accordingly before execution.

The official PAL documentation will be attached at the end of this article for reference.

Example for including ISLM into Embeddings

*ISLM Connectivity
   DATA(lo_vector_api) =  cl_aic_islm_embed_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance( 'EMBEDDING' ).

  To create the Intelligent Scenario please refer this blog:
 Unlocking the Power of Generative AI with Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)

Common error we face while working with PAL procedures:
Could not execute 'CALL SYS.AFLLANG_WRAPPER_PROCEDURE_CREATE ('area_name', 'function_name', 'schema_name', ...' SAP DBTech JDBC: [259]: invalid table name: Could not find table/view SIGNATURE_TABLE in schema PA0001: line 2 col 34 (at pos 107).

How to Resolve this problem?.

The above-mentioned error usually occurs when the mandatory fields in the parameter table are missing or incorrectly defined.

Each PAL algorithm has its own official SAP documentation that specifies the required parameter fields and their data types. It‚Äôs important to refer to the respective document while creating the parameter table to avoid such errors.

SAP PAL Documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/319d36de4fd64ac3afbf91b1fb3ce8de/pal-procedures-f652a81.html?locale=en-US 

Conclusion
SAP HANA PAL enables performing machine learning directly inside the HANA database, ensuring faster processing and real-time insights. With algorithms like clustering, classification, and regression, it helps build intelligent, data-driven applications seamlessly integrated within the SAP environment.

What's Next?


Here are some other important blogs to learn HANA PAL:
Exploring ML Explainability in SAP HANA PAL - AutoML

Text Embedding Service in SAP HANA Cloud Predictive Analysis Library (PAL)

entry.title: Re: How to read/write SAP CPI Datastore from Groovy
entry.content:
If you should not use these methods to access List<Data> from a DataStore containing JSON content, then how are you intended to get e.g. all entries of a DataStore instead of using these methods?

The DataStore Select building block fails to retrieve data if the content of an element is not XML. It even fails if there is any incorrect data in the DataStore. So while you actually store strings, and nothing ensures that it is XML, you can only retrieve if every element in the Store is XML. Btw. it is very strange, that in 2026 you are not able to operate on JSON content.

entry.title: SAP Joule Integration with SuccessFactors (Custom & Standard Portlet Support)
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team,

We are currently in the final phase of implementing SAP Joule with SAP SuccessFactors and are preparing for an upcoming go-live. During our testing and validation cycles, we have identified critical limitations that are impacting our Joule use cases and overall readiness.

We are submitting this as a High Priority Enhancement Request, as the issues directly affect business adoption and scope finalization.

Issue 1: Lack of Support for Custom Portlets / Custom MDF Objects

Description:
Our SuccessFactors landscape includes several custom portlets and custom MDF objects that store critical employee and business data. Currently, SAP Joule is unable to retrieve, interpret, or respond with information from these custom portlets.

We have reviewed the official Joule implementation and configuration guides; however, we did not find any documented configuration, extensibility option, or workaround that allows Joule to consume data from custom portlets or MDF objects.

Business Impact:

  • Limits Joule‚Äôs usability to only a subset of standard data
  • Prevents adoption of Joule for organization-specific use cases
  • Reduces ROI on Joule implementation
  • Forces continued manual navigation and reporting for custom data

Request / Enhancement Ask:

  1. Please confirm whether SAP Joule currently supports custom portlets or custom MDF objects.
  2. If supported:
    • Kindly share the required configuration steps, permissions, APIs, or extensibility options.
  3. If not supported:
    • Please advise on the product roadmap for custom object support.
    • Suggest any recommended alternative approach to expose custom data for Joule-based use cases.

Issue 2: Joule Not Working for Certain Standard SuccessFactors Portlets

Description:
We have also identified that Joule is not functioning as expected for the following standard SuccessFactors portlets:

  • Bank Information
  • Dependent Information

Despite these being standard delivered portlets, Joule does not return, process, or interact with data from these areas during testing.

Business Impact:

  • Incomplete employee self-service experience
  • Limits Joule‚Äôs effectiveness for HR and employee queries
  • Creates inconsistencies across supported and unsupported data domains

Request / Enhancement Ask:

  1. Please validate whether Bank Information and Dependent Information portlets are officially supported by Joule.
  2. Share any required prerequisites, role-based permissions, or configuration settings needed to enable Joule functionality for these portlets.
  3. Confirm whether this behavior is:
    • A known issue
    • A documented product limitation
    • Planned for enhancement in upcoming releases

Priority & Go-Live Impact

Given our upcoming go-live, clarity on the above items is critical for:

  • Finalizing Joule use cases
  • Managing business expectations
  • Determining scope and adoption readiness

We would appreciate your guidance, confirmation, and any available documentation or roadmap insights at the earliest.

Thank you for your continued support. We look forward to your response.

entry.title: Re: Select package size to solve 'Time out' Dump.
entry.content:
With this code, I've got a short dump DBSQL_INVALID_CURSOR at FETCH NEXT CURSOR (ABAP 7.58 SP 1):

OPEN CURSOR WITH HOLD (cursor) FOR
    SELECT *
      FROM ekpo.

DATA answer TYPE c LENGTH 1.
CALL FUNCTION 'POPUP_TO_CONFIRM'
  EXPORTING  text_question  = 'Continue?'
  IMPORTING  answer         = answer
  EXCEPTIONS text_not_found = 1
             OTHERS         = 2.

DATA itab TYPE TABLE OF ekpo.
DATA(percentage) = 0.
DO.

  FETCH NEXT CURSOR @cursor " <===== SHORT DUMP AT FIRST ITERATION
  INTO TABLE @itab
  PACKAGE SIZE 18000.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  percentage += 1.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SAPGUI_PROGRESS_INDICATOR'
    EXPORTING percentage = percentage
              text       = 'In progress'.

ENDDO.
CLOSE CURSOR cursor.

entry.title: Re: SAP Joule Integration with SuccessFactors (Custom & S...
entry.content:
Hi,

I‚Äôll try to answer your questions. Since Joule capabilities are still evolving, they are not yet fully finalized across all SAP products. This will continue to improve over time, but for the most accurate and up-to-date information, it‚Äôs best to consult the product team directly or raise a support ticket.

All custom enhancements can be achieved using Joule Studio and SAP Build. Currently, you can create custom skills and expose custom APIs via Integration Suite / SAP BTP (referred to as Actions in SAP Build). These custom Joule skills can then be deployed to the global Joule instance (environment), making them available to all users.

Standard SuccessFactors use cases supported by Joule are available here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/capabilities-guide/use-cases-supported-in-joule?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Kind regards,
Mateusz Kwasniewski

entry.title: SAP Developer News January 8th,, 2026
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION 

CAP December 2025 release 

  • CAP December 2025 release notes https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/releases/dec25  
  • SAP Developer News episode covering Status-Transition Flows and the CAP November 2025 release https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BkCPoH7VKHg  
  • A simple exploration of status transition flows in CAP (blog post) https://qmacro.org/blog/posts/2025/12/08/a-simple-exploration-of-status-transition-flows-in-cap/  
  • Axiom AXI001 What not how https://github.com/qmacro/capref/blob/main/axioms/AXI001.md  
  • A new Hands-on SAP Dev mini-series on the core expression language in CDS (blog post) https://qmacro.org/blog/posts/2025/12/09/a-new-hands-on-sap-dev-mini-series-on-the-core-expression-language-in-cds/  
  • CDS expressions in CAP - Under the hood - Part 1 (upcoming live stream) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aiE20i5BP70  
  • Best Practice BES006 Compose with reuse in mind https://github.com/qmacro/capref/blob/main/bestpractices/BES006.md  
  • The OData "Common" Vocabulary's FieldControlType definitions https://sap.github.io/odata-vocabularies/vocabularies/Common.html#FieldControlType  

2025 set the pace, 2026 wins the race: ABAP 

  • Blog Post: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/2025-set-the-pace-2026-wins-the-race-abap-ai-with-joule-vs-code-and-ccm/ba-p/14302433 

What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì 2025-Q4 

  • Overview: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/what-s-new-in-sap-hana-cloud-december-2025/ba-p/14295366 
  • New Machine Learning, NLP and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q4: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-machine-learning-nlp-and-ai-features-in-sap-hana-cloud-2025-q4/ba-p/14293152 
  • SAP CodeJam on Foundations of AI applications with the SAP HANA Cloud -- ML, Vectors, Knowledge Graph: https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-codejam-blog-posts/sap-codejam-topics/ba-p/221407#codejam1  

 Application Vulnerability Report 

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-application-vulnerability-report-for-cloudfoundry-applications/ba-p/14281684 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 CAP December 2025 release 

6:20 2025 set the pace, 2026 wins the race: ABAP 

7:22 What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì 2025-Q4 

9:36 Application Vulnerability Report 

10:32 Devtoberfest Winner Jose Pereira 

Transcript

00;00;00;08 - 00;00;05;26

This is the SAP Developer News for January 8th, 2026.

00;00;05;29 - 00;00;09;26

Over the holiday period, the CAP team delivered a nice present for us.

00;00;10;00 - 00;00;44;20

The December 2025 release. Let's take a quick look through the highlights. But before we do, let's check out the new FEATURE STATUS BADGES that are appearing more and more - in fact, there are a few in the notes for this release.

As we all know our Greek alphabet, we can correctly surmise that while BETA features are post-experimental and still possibly subject to change ... GAMMA features, not to be confused with the type of radiation that created The Incredible Hulk, are pretty much finalised and ready to use & test thoroughly.

00;00;44;22 - 00;01;19;15

Two such features that are at GAMMA level in this release are Status-Transition Flows and Declarative Constraints.

We covered Status-Transition Flows in a previous news item for the previous release, and there's an overview in this blog post we have for you.

So let's instead take a brief look at the super exciting Declarative Constraints. There are new possibilities with the @assert annotation to define complex constraints, in your CDS model.

00;01;19;18 - 00;01;50;01

That's right, declaratively. We should always strive to PUSH outwards, pushing logic up into the declarative model, and queries & data manipulation down to the database, which goes hand in hand with CAP‚Äôs axiom WHAT NOT HOW.

The conditions are expressed in another domain specific language in CDS - CXL - CDS Expression Language.

00;01;50;01 - 00;02;19;07

And, almost as if we'd planned it, there‚Äôs a new Hands-on SAP Dev live stream series on CXL starting Friday next week, with me and one of the fab members of the CAP compiler team, Patrice. Don't miss it!

CAP‚Äôs support for hierarchical tree views has just become a lot more streamlined, with a new @hierarchy annotation replacing a ton of OData specific ones.

00;02;19;08 - 00;02;46;26

Now that's what I call simple reuse, and cap is an incredibly important idea and a best practice to add in that context. There's a new command CDS export, with which you can create API client packages from your CDS service. Definitions. The output is a full featured cap reuse package that can be published to and pulled from npm registries.

00;02;46;29 - 00;03;15;23

Now that‚Äôs what I call simple.

Reuse in CAP is an incredibly important idea, and best practice too, and in that context, there‚Äôs a new command cds export with which you can create API client packages from your CDS service definitions; the output is a full-featured CAP reuse package that can be published to and pulled from NPM registries. If exporting via EDMX is the lossy MP3 audio format, then cds export gives us a lossless transfer, more like FLAC.

By the way, if you're interested to learn more about reuse in CAP, with NPM packages, we've a new blog post series Modules, modularity & reuse in CDS models which you might be interested in, with parts 1 and 2 already published.

00;03;15;26 - 00;03;45;29

In the CDS Language & Compiler topic, there's an enhancement that will appeal to those of you who develop and serve multiple frontends from the app/ directory. Now CDS file content from all ./app/* subdirectories will be fetched and loaded (say, with cds build or cds serve) instead of just from the app/ directory itself. This means we don't have to use an index.cds file in the app/ directory to import what we need.

00;03;46;01 - 00;04;19;26

Staying in the CDS Language & Compiler area, there's another enhancement that allows us to use symbols not only for enums defined in CDS, but now also for enums in OData annotations. The example in the release notes in Capire is great, because not only does it illustrate the enhancement, but it also causes the curious amongst us to use our brains and go to find out where the relation between 1 and Readonly, and between 7 and Mandatory, is defined.

00;04;19;26 - 00;04;51;01

And of course it's in OData's ‚ÄúCommon‚Äù vocabulary, contributed by SAP.

In the Node.js runtime topic, it is now possible to make direct CRUD requests on draft-enabled entities; for example, instead of the EDIT-PATCH-SAVE sequence, you can now just send a direct UPDATE request.

Also, event queue processing has been consolidated into a default queue ... and custom queues, and there has been a change to the db-related guarantee, from ‚Äòat least once‚Äô to ‚Äòexactly once‚Äô.

00;04;51;01 - 00;05;23;03

Related guarantee from at least once to exactly once. Finally, in the NodeJS runtime topic, there has been some cleanup of the model reflection APIs. Some function uses have been deprecated and the text entities are now available in a text property of the corresponding localized entity. Moving to the Java runtime topic, there are some important changes related to deep updates for draft enabled entities.

00;05;23;06 - 00;05;52;09

Finally in the Node.js runtime topic, there has been some clean up of the model reflection APIs. Some function usages have been deprecated, and the .texts entities are now available in a texts property of the corresponding localised entity.

In the Java runtime, there are some important changes related to deep updates for draft-enabled entities.

00;05;52;11 - 00;06;23;25

Now, as well as support for active entities, there‚Äôs also deep update support for inactive entities too, as long as the keys are included.

Additionally, there‚Äôs a new as(String alias) method on the CqnValue interface; with that, it‚Äôs possible to create aliased values directly, making it easier to build queries with aliased values.

In the Tools topic, there‚Äôs a Kyma convenience now for the cds up command; if your project contains Helm deployment resources, and no mta.yaml file, then you don't need to specify the --to k8s option explicitly any more.

And last but not least, in the Plugins topic, the Node.js plugin @SAP/cds-rfc now supports multitenancy.

There are links to everything I've mentioned, and more ... in the description.

00;06;23;27 - 00;06;45;04

In this blog post, Simona reflects on how 2025 laid the groundwork for AI powered ABAP development and gives us a clear line of sight into where things are going in 2026. One big highlight from the blogpost is that Joule for developers will remain free for another year, giving us more time to explore AI assisted coding in real projects.

00;06;45;07 - 00;07;15;00

The blog post walks us through the evolution of AI last year and what's to come. Smart tooling with the AI workflow, deeper integration with VS code, and a renowned focus on custom code migration using AI, all designed to help developers be more productive and modernize their code bases. And that's really the strategy going into 2020. Shipping early, scaling smart, and keeping the ABAP core clean in 2025 is about unlocking what I can do.

00;07;15;07 - 00;07;22;12

Then 2026 will make ABAP AI the core of AI about development.

00;07;22;15 - 00;07;54;05

The Q4 2025 release of SAP HANA Cloud brings many updates designed to streamline your workflow and unlock new possibilities. Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new.

Let's start with SAP HANA Cloud Central, which now supports background processing for long-running SQL statements that continue even after closing your browser. A new consolidated view of HDI schemas and containers provides quick access to HDI artifacts and their metadata.

00;07;54;08 - 00;08;36;26

SAP Business Data Cloud integration is streamlined‚Äîdata products are automatically exposed as virtual tables, reducing manual setup and accelerating data reuse.

Calculation view modeling adds column lineage via SQL table functions, dynamic input parameters for MDS cube conversions, and runtime-evaluated restricted columns. Joins are enhanced with support for left outer joins in star joins.

This release introduces the ability to transform property graphs into semantic knowledge graphs without requiring redesign of data models, enabling flexible switching between paradigms on the same data for your use cases.

00;08;36;28 - 00;09;10;09

For developers and data scientists, AI and machine learning capabilities have undergone significant enhancements. The new Unified Time Series procedure provides a consistent interface across algorithms, simplifying development. Text embedding models have been improved to reduce output dimensions without sacrificing accuracy, and the new cross and convert model. In an NLP service ensures more precise search results. Ranking with the Hana Experiment Monitor user interface.

00;09;10;11 - 00;09;34;05

The final SAP CodeJam of 2025 took place in Istanbul, with a focus on AI in SAP HANA Cloud. The next one will happen in February in Berlin, and rest assured, it will be updated with some of these cool new enhancements. You can request this CodeJam topic in your location also!

00;09;34;08 - 00;09;38;22

Also see all the.

00;09;38;25 - 00;10;08;14

Why not start the year off right? With the cleanest, safest applications you can. That's what the new application vulnerability report service for on SAP. BTP focuses on Cloud Foundry applications. Is exactly for this new service. Now in beta will allow you to scan your running applications on SAP, BTP on a regular basis and look for critical vulnerabilities. Don't wait until something happens to one of your applications to find out that there's a vulnerability in it.

00;10;08;16 - 00;10;31;19

Be proactive and find out in advance. So I encourage you to check out this brand new service. I'll put the link to the blog post that describes it, as well as goes through the setup process. It's very easy to use and you can start getting your reports today, so I would encourage you to do so.

There was kind of a learning journey that you did. Yeah. Our bosses always incentive us to look forward. And WhatsApp has to offer. Even if we don't do work on it.

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP: Execute Business Object Interface from action
entry.content:
Hello @Andre_Fischer  @ChristianLopez , I‚Äôm also very interested in this topic.

I‚Äôm not sure I understand how the improvement mentioned in the roadmap relates to Christian Lopez‚Äôs issue. I‚Äôve developed a similar application (also using I_MaterialDocumentTP), and in my case, the messages are reflected in the UI without any problem.

The real challenge is that these messages are not tied to a specific table row. For example, if my action creates one material document per row, I want to know which row produced which success or error message when the action is executed on multiple rows. This feels like a very basic requirement, and I don‚Äôt understand why it‚Äôs so complicated to handle properly.

I haven‚Äôt tried the Background Processing Framework or job-based workarounds, but I‚Äôm not even sure they would work, since material document creation is always tricky due to commit handling (which, fortunately, is managed correctly by the RAP Business Object I_MaterialDocumentTP‚Äîa pleasant surprise). You‚Äôve helped in the past to retrieve the created material document ID (which is also tricky but doable). However, as I can see in this GitHub repository, errors are simply not handled in SAP‚Äôs examples.

https://github.com/SAP-samples/abap-platform-rap-workshops/blob/main/rap6xx/rap610/exercises/ex4/README.md
